The iron railing front of the Bank Of the United States
on Chesnul street. Philadelphia, has been taken down. in

COLONIZATION BILL.--The bill appropr-

land to the objects OF the Colonization Society, has
passed both branches OF the legislature and has be-
come law.
FRIDAY, March 16, 1927.

FROM RIO DE JANEIRo.-By the ship General
Smith, Captain jones' at this port yesterday from
Rio de Janero. We have received advces to the 8h
January inclusive. One OF our letters says -" The
Emperor returned on the 18th instant from ST.
Catharlnes and Rio Crande, and Immediately on his
arrival displaced his ministers and made new ap'
pointmentu. The reason for this sudden change ia
said to have originated in his ministers not being
sufficiently respectful to the Countess Santos, du-
ring his absence.


Nothing decisive in relation to the war between
Buenos Ayres end Brazil had grown out Of the En-
pcrors visit to Rio Grande. The accounts az to
the duration of the contradictory, let.
ters stating that il must speedily be brought to
close, from the heavy burdens which it imposed on
The biegerents-whe others assert that both par
lies were determined to prosecute the war with vi
gor. The resources Of the Brazilian government
are said to be much exhausted, and to defray he
expenses of the war, i, is said that the monies which
are paid into the Custom House FOR duties, are
drawn out every day. The main body Of the Bra.
lillian army was concentrated a. Rio Grande. 1t is
reported 10 be in wretchcd condition, disturbed by
dlssentions desu,e Of every kind Of provisions ex-
cspi fresh beef, and nearly so Of clothing

ned BY the violence Of the wind, mocked every

The next building. which caught fire, were the


sy Lancasterian School House. in the rear. (tron-


np on Fen Church street and Mrs. BrambIe's

nd heyond these, the fire swept every building


the large brick house at the corner of Mariners

y ';ie. including all those on Mariners street.
The sight was awful and heart rending beyond


description. 1t was not regular progressive fire !:
fl had been, our fire companies would soon have

kody of the fire, as well as those near, snted

nHoUsE OF DELEGATES, IL o'clock, NJ.


March 10, 1897. {


On yesterday evening, Mr.. Tyson submitted an
order to give the bill for the promotion of Internal
Improvement priority over all other business Of to
/ day. To-day at an early hour, on motion Of MIR.
stricker, the bill was called up Several amend.
ments were offered with a view Of defeating, or
calculated to defeat, the bill but they siren
uousIy and successfully resisted by Messrs. Tyson,
|Suicker and Duval. At length the question was
taken on the passage of the bill, and decided in
1.-THE affirmative by vote of 40 to S5. In one hour
|ths bill passed the Senate and became taW. The
passage Of this bill is a great triumph for the
state Of Mary land and particularly the city Of
Baltimore. 1t gives S50O.00o to the Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal, on condition Of Congress, subscri-
bins for 10000 shares. 1t gives the ike sum of
100000 TO rHE SUSQUEH ANNA CANAL,
provided 5000 shares should be first subscribed by
bona fde subscribers. Now is the time for the city
of Baltimore to take the start in the field of great
ness. Let her people put forth all their strength
let the City Councils unlock your resources-you
will have your Rail Road to the West-your sus.
quehanna Canal to the North and West-the trca-
sures of three mions of enterplisng people will
flow into your lap, and Baltimore will yet become
The first city Of this Union.

.Ertract of letter to the Editors Of the Balti.


more .9merican, dnted

annapolis, March 10, 1897.


A bill from the House of Delegates on the sub
ject of Internal Improvement, has just passed the
Senate. affirmative, Messrs- Forrest, Heath, john
son, Kennedy, Marriott, Nelson. Sewell-7.


Negative, Messrs Dennis. Harrison, Reese.
Whitely--4. Several Senators friendly to the bill
we're absent.
This bill accords with the wishes Of the Chesa-
peake and Ohio Canal Convention. and repeals the
proyisos in our Internal Improvement Law, which
prevented the State of Maryland from becoming
subscribers TO the amount of half million of dol
lars to the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. 1t also
allows the same amount to the Susquehannah Canal,
and authorizes an advance of twenty thousand dol
lars to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal.


Maryland has therefore taken her stand in favor
Of Internal Improvement, and her policy will re-
main unchanged for many years; during the term,
at all events, of the present Senate, who hold their
seats until September, 1881.


Maryland has shown that she is ready and will
ling to use all the means in her power to promote
the happiness of her citizens and the welfare of the
whole Union.

DIED-In Washington City, on the 18th inst, RICHARD
BLAND LEE, Esq aged IS years.


Mr.. LEE a Member of the First Congress of the
United States from the State of Virginia. and served in the
House Of Representatives for several years He was. in
that important public service, contemporary of Mr. MAD
IsoN and enjoyed his friendship and esteem, of which, in
later days, he has received distinguished marks

Corporal Harker.-This pugnacious little man
still persists in asserting that we have misrepre-
sented his language. in the quotation from the
Delaware Gazette of Nov. /, 1922 The assertion
is downright falsehood, and the Corporal's refu-
sal to republish his remarks of that date, is the
strongest proof OF our correctness and will be re-
fcelved by the public as evidence that he stands
guilty of the charges which have been made against
him OF inconsistency and hypocrisy in advocating
the cause of s.Old Hickory" the man, to abuse
whom, he formerly raked together all the dirty
epithets that yugarism could afford. We must
again observe that our object is not to notice the
CorporaFs personal abuse of ourselves. This we
disregard, feeling satisfied that his blackguardism
cannot injure any person. We wish now to call
our readers to the cowardly manner in which the
Corporal attempts to make his escape from the
unpleasant situation in which he has been placed
by our recent exposure of his inconsistency. A
doughty little fellow like him, who talks about
shouldering his rifle, and has boasted of his militia
~ exploits during the late war, ought to be ashamed
to sneak oft in such a manner. You must come
back, Corporal. We cannot suffer you to get out
OF the scrape, by swearing that you will not again
notice US. No, no-this will not do. You must act
more like man More like what you profess to
bean honorable mana man of valor. Your
mere denial OF our charge, and yonr refusal to ac.
cept of challenge, cannot save you. Even





your want of candor and magnanmity in this af-
fair. Some of them are laughing at you. Others
despise you for your cowardice. Had YOU come
out at first like an honest man, and given your
reasons for the change in your opinion of General
Jackson, offered satisfactory plea for your for
mer abuse, and present support, of him, you might
have been preserved from those mortifyng feelings
which have emblttered your mind and rendered
you reckless of decency and truth.


tbok 49,.
guilty of misrepresenting MIR. Harker's sentiments
respecting Gen. Jackson, in the quotation which
we have several times made from the Delaware Ga
zettc of Nov. /, 1922. In that paper, which may
be seen at this office, Mr.. Harker says, that when
certain points substantiated, we may be bet
ter able to Judge OF the relative claims of the ssve-
rat candidates." These s. several candidates.
were Messrs, Clay, Clinton, Jackson, Adams, Cal
houn, and Crawford, whose names he had just be-
fore mentioned in the same article from which our
quotation is made. He then proceeds to say that


"Of ALL the gentlemen named Gen. Jaekssn appears
to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
a Of energy, will doubt but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, much en-
eryy extremely dangerous; AND have IN THE
GENERAL such DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TloNS of the country, such DISPOSITION TO place
himself ABOVE ITS la1vs, AND such an INCLINATION 10
TRAMPLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
they stood in composition with HIS OWN INTEREST or
FEELINGS, as should render the citizens of the United
States pery cautious about placing him in the first office
within their gift.''


five are guilty of fmisrepresenting MIR. Harker's
sentiments, how easy is it for him to prove US so,
by repubishing the article which contains the above
extract. This we dare him to do. Although we
believe he cannot muster courage sufficient to ac
cept the challenge, we will wait little longer with
him, still intending to republish it ourselves, at
such time as we may deem expedient.

many Two Dollar Notes in circulation purporting to be
the Merchants Bank. in the city of New York they are
OF the letter B dated New York, March 1896 No. $500
they may be easily detected by measuring both ends
left.


PHILADELPHIA, March 49,
Counterfeit Ten Dollar Notes Of the Commercial Bank
Of Pennsylvania, (old plate, letter c. payable to H. Clay
are still in circulation. with the signature of the presen,
cashier, Benjamin p. Smith, instead of j. Williams as in
above plate have nearly all been redeemed: The notes
now issued by the bank have different vgnete with the
miniatures of Washington and Franklin the margin.
Richmond, Ya., March 7-Noes of the Farmers Bank
Of Virginia, the Mother Bank which the heads of
Washington ard Jefferson, have been altered from FIVE
nifty dollars The figures at each end and the word pe
in the body have been extracted and large figures so
the word hf'y inserted by stamp and neatly executed.


Inc small eagle between the signatures OF the President
and Cashier has also been taken and the figures so
stamped in its place. The public may guard against i'm.
position by noticing, that neither of the heads above


toned are on the borders Of The genuine fifty dollar
OF the Mother Bank the borders of which have the de-
nomination at one end, and the of the bank the

The woollen factory, at Jeweu City, near Nor.
wich, Conn. owned by the Griswold Manufac,ur.
ing Company, took fire recently while the workmen
we're at breakfast and their return was 60 far en-.
veloped in flames that all efforts TO save it we're IN.
availing. All the machinery and large part Of the
stock in the main building was consumed with it,
The loss is stated to be between and 90 900 dol
ars-the principal part Of which, it is said falls up
on the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.
Lnsanay.--A dreadful accident took place al
Marcellns, Hopkins CO. (Pa.) on tbe 24,h uik Mrs
Johnson. an accomplished lady Of fortune, in fl
OF Temporary insanity, poisoned her four youngest
children, and then threw herself from a window Of
the third story Of her mansion house Mr.. ]. rode
up to his door at the very moment that his unhap-
py wife was taken up lifeless. His phrenzy and
despair may be imagined. but cannot be described.


STATE LEGISLATURE.


NeW York, March 12.--In the House, several
petitions were presented from citizens of the west
ern countless for aid in investigating the mysterious
circumstance ofthe disappearance Of William Nor
gan. The petitions were referred to the commit.
lee on courts of justice.


Philadelphia, March 13.-The collection in the
Baptist Church in Second street. on Thursday even
ing last. for the benefit Of the Creeks was 16O dol
lars. The whole fund now exceeds Is 1000 dollars

FLORIDA SUGAR We have received specimen Of
nounced by Judges be superior the best Havana
gar Col Whe writes that he has received letters from
a dozen planters in North Carolina and Virginia, making
known their determination to to Florida and ask
ing for information. Col. Dumme told, will make
80 Hhds Sugar. notwithstanding the disadvantages under
which he labored, from about 35 acres of Cane.

notice, because it shows how extensive the trade
of the city must be which exhibits such an appear.
ance on one OF its numerous avenues-and it also
serves strongly to illustrate the Importance and
value of the contemplated Rail Road to the West.
the advantages of which, when compared with
those Of the ordinary turnpike road, are as twenty
to one in favor Of the former.-B Bait. american.


The Legislature of the State of VIRGINIA has
passed law confirming the Charter of the BaIti-
more and Ohio Rail Road Company. with only these
alterations: 1s. That the road shall not touch the
Ohio river lower down than the mouth of Little
kanawha river; that the damages for property ta-
ken or used for the construction Of the road, &C.
shal be determined as such affairs are now effected
by the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia; that
the penalty for inurng the road or property Of
Company, shall be the same as is inflicted for the
same offence against the public works of Virginia,
that is, the Penitentiary. The bill passed both
Houses Of the Legislature by an almost unanimous
vote.

yelling, IAN elevated wooden house) on the North;


nd heyond these, the fire swept every building


the large brick house at the corner of Mariners


t,eet on the East side of Church street, and to the


;orthern extremity of Fen Church street, West
y ';ie. including all those on Mariners street.
The sight was awful and heart rending beyond


description. 1t was not regular progressive fire !:
fl had been, our fire companies would soon have
&hecked its progress; but houses remote from the
kody of the fire, as well as those near, snted
kv the falling flakes and brands, and as many as
Twelve or fifteen, in detached situations, were on
lire at the same moment.


We have not time to give any thing like proba-
HE estimate Of the amount of property destroyed.
n the names of the individual sufferers. Between
Eorty and fifty families have been rendered house
esq. and the loss cannot be much short of 10000
[loars The Church, (ncuding lbs elegant organ
was insured for fifteen thousand dollars, in the Mu
kual Assurance Office, and we understand that most
of the houses Of any considerable value, also
Insured The fire might have been accidental, but
There is too much cause to apprehend that it was
|Ae work Of the lurking ncendary.

nHoUsE OF DELEGATES, IL o'clock, NJ.


March 10, 1897. {


On yesterday evening, Mr.. Tyson submitted an
order to give the bill for the promotion of Internal
Improvement priority over all other business Of to
/ day. To-day at an early hour, on motion Of MIR.
stricker, the bill was called up Several amend.
ments were offered with a view Of defeating, or
calculated to defeat, the bill but they siren
uousIy and successfully resisted by Messrs. Tyson,
|Suicker and Duval. At length the question was
taken on the passage of the bill, and decided in
1.-THE affirmative by vote of 40 to S5. In one hour
|ths bill passed the Senate and became taW. The
passage Of this bill is a great triumph for the
state Of Mary land and particularly the city Of
Baltimore. 1t gives S50O.00o to the Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal, on condition Of Congress, subscri-
bins for 10000 shares. 1t gives the ike sum of
100000 TO rHE SUSQUEH ANNA CANAL,
provided 5000 shares should be first subscribed by
bona fde subscribers. Now is the time for the city
of Baltimore to take the start in the field of great
ness. Let her people put forth all their strength
let the City Councils unlock your resources-you
will have your Rail Road to the West-your sus.
quehanna Canal to the North and West-the trca-
sures of three mions of enterplisng people will
flow into your lap, and Baltimore will yet become
The first city Of this Union.

full articles.headline: From the National Tateiligencer.
full articles.article:
annapolis, March 10, 1897.


A bill from the House of Delegates on the sub
ject of Internal Improvement, has just passed the
Senate. affirmative, Messrs- Forrest, Heath, john
son, Kennedy, Marriott, Nelson. Sewell-7.


Negative, Messrs Dennis. Harrison, Reese.
Whitely--4. Several Senators friendly to the bill
we're absent.
This bill accords with the wishes Of the Chesa-
peake and Ohio Canal Convention. and repeals the
proyisos in our Internal Improvement Law, which
prevented the State of Maryland from becoming
subscribers TO the amount of half million of dol
lars to the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. 1t also
allows the same amount to the Susquehannah Canal,
and authorizes an advance of twenty thousand dol
lars to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal.


Maryland has therefore taken her stand in favor
Of Internal Improvement, and her policy will re-
main unchanged for many years; during the term,
at all events, of the present Senate, who hold their
seats until September, 1881.


Maryland has shown that she is ready and will
ling to use all the means in her power to promote
the happiness of her citizens and the welfare of the
whole Union.

A. NAUDAIN, ANDREW GRAY,


JAMES BOOTH, Jr r. MANSFIELD.


TH0S w. ROGERS,

DIED-In Washington City, on the 18th inst, RICHARD
BLAND LEE, Esq aged IS years.


Mr.. LEE a Member of the First Congress of the
United States from the State of Virginia. and served in the
House Of Representatives for several years He was. in
that important public service, contemporary of Mr. MAD
IsoN and enjoyed his friendship and esteem, of which, in
later days, he has received distinguished marks

Corporal Harker.-This pugnacious little man
still persists in asserting that we have misrepre-
sented his language. in the quotation from the
Delaware Gazette of Nov. /, 1922 The assertion
is downright falsehood, and the Corporal's refu-
sal to republish his remarks of that date, is the
strongest proof OF our correctness and will be re-
fcelved by the public as evidence that he stands
guilty of the charges which have been made against
him OF inconsistency and hypocrisy in advocating
the cause of s.Old Hickory" the man, to abuse
whom, he formerly raked together all the dirty
epithets that yugarism could afford. We must
again observe that our object is not to notice the
CorporaFs personal abuse of ourselves. This we
disregard, feeling satisfied that his blackguardism
cannot injure any person. We wish now to call
our readers to the cowardly manner in which the
Corporal attempts to make his escape from the
unpleasant situation in which he has been placed
by our recent exposure of his inconsistency. A
doughty little fellow like him, who talks about
shouldering his rifle, and has boasted of his militia
~ exploits during the late war, ought to be ashamed
to sneak oft in such a manner. You must come
back, Corporal. We cannot suffer you to get out
OF the scrape, by swearing that you will not again
notice US. No, no-this will not do. You must act
more like man More like what you profess to
bean honorable mana man of valor. Your
mere denial OF our charge, and yonr refusal to ac.
cept of challenge, cannot save you. Even





your want of candor and magnanmity in this af-
fair. Some of them are laughing at you. Others
despise you for your cowardice. Had YOU come
out at first like an honest man, and given your
reasons for the change in your opinion of General
Jackson, offered satisfactory plea for your for
mer abuse, and present support, of him, you might
have been preserved from those mortifyng feelings
which have emblttered your mind and rendered
you reckless of decency and truth.


tbok 49,.
guilty of misrepresenting MIR. Harker's sentiments
respecting Gen. Jackson, in the quotation which
we have several times made from the Delaware Ga
zettc of Nov. /, 1922. In that paper, which may
be seen at this office, Mr.. Harker says, that when
certain points substantiated, we may be bet
ter able to Judge OF the relative claims of the ssve-
rat candidates." These s. several candidates.
were Messrs, Clay, Clinton, Jackson, Adams, Cal
houn, and Crawford, whose names he had just be-
fore mentioned in the same article from which our
quotation is made. He then proceeds to say that


"Of ALL the gentlemen named Gen. Jaekssn appears
to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
a Of energy, will doubt but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, much en-
eryy extremely dangerous; AND have IN THE
GENERAL such DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TloNS of the country, such DISPOSITION TO place
himself ABOVE ITS la1vs, AND such an INCLINATION 10
TRAMPLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
they stood in composition with HIS OWN INTEREST or
FEELINGS, as should render the citizens of the United
States pery cautious about placing him in the first office
within their gift.''


five are guilty of fmisrepresenting MIR. Harker's
sentiments, how easy is it for him to prove US so,
by repubishing the article which contains the above
extract. This we dare him to do. Although we
believe he cannot muster courage sufficient to ac
cept the challenge, we will wait little longer with
him, still intending to republish it ourselves, at
such time as we may deem expedient.

full articles.article:
NOTICE is hereby given, conformaby with the drcc
IN ton the Sd section Of the suboned act of Congress
that the Commssoners with their Clerk, appointed TO
carry into effect the provisions of the said act will
in this City the tenth day of July next and enter
upon the execution Of their duties:


An Act to provide for the adjustment of claims of


entitled to indemncation under the first article of the


Treaty Of Client, aid for the distribution, among such


claimants OF the sum paid and TO be paid, by the Gov


eminent of Great Britain under Convention between


the United States and his Britannia Maes,y, concluded,
at London on the thirteenth Of November thousand


eight hundred and twenty-six


BE enacted BY the Senate and House Of Rebresentatives
Of the United States Of 4merica in Congress assembled That
authorized. by and with the advice and consent of the
Senate, to appoint three Commissioners, and Clerk
who shall constitute Commission, to carry into effect the
purposes Of this act.


Sec. and be further enacted That all records tcu.
ments and other papers, which in possession of the
Commissioners constituting the mixed commission under
the Treaty OF Ghent far the under the
troll of the Government Of the United Sates shall be de-
livered to the Commissioners under this act.


Sec. 8 And be il further enacted, That the said Com.
mssones, majority of them, with their Clerk, shall
convene in the City of Washington, the tenth day Of
July and shall proceed to execute the duties Of their
commission, and the Secretary of State shall be- and he is
hereby, authorized and required forthwith, after the pass
ing of this act to give notice of the said intended meet
ng to be published in public gazeites in the
City Of Washington and in the States from which the proc
perty Of claimants who have heretofore registered their
Claims shall have been taken.


See. f. .and be further enacted That the said Commits
soners shall proceed, Immediately meeting
the City Of Washington, with all convenient despatch, to
arrange and docket the several claims and to consider the
evidence which shall have been, which may be- offered
by the respective claimants allowing such further time for
the production of such further evidence they may
qure, they shall think reasonable and just and they
shall thereupon proceed to determine the said claims and
to award distribution of the sad fund among the several
claimants, according to their respective rights.


Sec. S. And be ii further enacted That The said Com.
nssoners shall be, ana they hereby, authorized and
empowered make all needfu rules and regulations not
venng the laws of the land the provisions of this
act, the provisions Of the said Treaty and Convention
for carrying their said Commission into full and complete
effect.


Sec. g. And be further enacted, That the aid Com.
mssoners shall be entitled to, and allowed the Of
three thousand dollars annum each and the Cerk Of
the said commission shall be entitled to- and allowed
of thousand FIVE hundred dollarA per dur.
ing the continuance of the said commission and the Pres
dent of the United States shall be, and he hereby autho
rzed to make such provision for the incidental expenses
of the said commission shall appear to him reasonable
and proper and the said salaries and expenses shall be
paid out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise ap
propriated


Sec T. find be trt6er enacted, That the said Com.
mssioners and Clerk shall severay take oath for the
faithful performance of the duties Of their respective off,
ces.


Sec. And Be It further enacted That the Commission
hereby created shall not continue after the end Of the next
session of Congress.


Sec g. Qnd5e further enacted, That the payment of
such claims may be admitted and adjusted by the said
Commissioners, the major part Of them, to
exceeding twelve hundred and four Thousand nine hun
dred and sixty dollars shall be made out Of any moneys
the Treasury not otherwise sppropraed tia, is to say:
soon and often as any of the said claims shall be
adudged 10 be valid, and the principal amount shall be
ascertaned there shall be paid such claims respective
y, equal to seventyve per cenum Of the principal
thereof ascertaned, and at the termination Of the
time hereby fixed for the dissolution of the Boad or such
earlier dissolution thereof may be determined upon by
the Board ITSELF after it shall have examined and decided
upon all the claims aforesaid the balance Of all such sums
shall be adjudged the claimants shall be paid PRO
vided The whole adudged or awarded to them, col
lectvely shall not exceed the aforesaid sum Of twelve hum
and if the whole adudgrd awarded, shall exceed
that amount, the claimants SHALL respectively receive in
to the sums awarded to them, respectvely
part of the balance thereof remaining for distribution
Sec 10. .7nd be il further enacted That all moneys al
ready received and all which shall hereafter be received
under the Convention aforesaid signed at London, on hc
thirteenth of November, thousand eight hundred and
twenty.six shall be paid into the Treasury Of the United
States


Sec II And ls further enacted, That as the
said commission shall be executed and completed the
Cords documents and all other papers in the possession Of
the commission, its officers, shall be deposited in the
Office of the Secretary OF State.


deposited in the Department OF State and by mistake
omitted be placed the denitye list delivered to the
former Commissioners shall be- and are hereby required
be added thereto and the said claimants shall be EMIT
led the rights and benefits as if such claims had
been placed the said de6nve list in terms of the third
article of the Convention concluded at ST. Petersburg
The twelfth day of July, eighteen hundred and twenty-five.


JOHN w. TAYLOR,


Speaker Of the House of Representatives.


NATHL. MACON,


President of the Senate, pro empore,
Approved Cd March, 1927.


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS

BEWARE OF COUNTERFEIrs There are a erea,
many Two Dollar Notes in circulation purporting to be
the Merchants Bank. in the city of New York they are
OF the letter B dated New York, March 1896 No. $500
they may be easily detected by measuring both ends
left.


PHILADELPHIA, March 49,
Counterfeit Ten Dollar Notes Of the Commercial Bank
Of Pennsylvania, (old plate, letter c. payable to H. Clay
are still in circulation. with the signature of the presen,
cashier, Benjamin p. Smith, instead of j. Williams as in
above plate have nearly all been redeemed: The notes
now issued by the bank have different vgnete with the
miniatures of Washington and Franklin the margin.
Richmond, Ya., March 7-Noes of the Farmers Bank
Of Virginia, the Mother Bank which the heads of
Washington ard Jefferson, have been altered from FIVE
nifty dollars The figures at each end and the word pe
in the body have been extracted and large figures so
the word hf'y inserted by stamp and neatly executed.


Inc small eagle between the signatures OF the President
and Cashier has also been taken and the figures so
stamped in its place. The public may guard against i'm.
position by noticing, that neither of the heads above


toned are on the borders Of The genuine fifty dollar
OF the Mother Bank the borders of which have the de-
nomination at one end, and the of the bank the
other Compiler
The woollen factory, at Jeweu City, near Nor.
wich, Conn. owned by the Griswold Manufac,ur.
ing Company, took fire recently while the workmen
we're at breakfast and their return was 60 far en-.
veloped in flames that all efforts TO save it we're IN.
availing. All the machinery and large part Of the
stock in the main building was consumed with it,
The loss is stated to be between and 90 900 dol
ars-the principal part Of which, it is said falls up
on the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.
Lnsanay.--A dreadful accident took place al
Marcellns, Hopkins CO. (Pa.) on tbe 24,h uik Mrs
Johnson. an accomplished lady Of fortune, in fl
OF Temporary insanity, poisoned her four youngest
children, and then threw herself from a window Of
the third story Of her mansion house Mr.. ]. rode
up to his door at the very moment that his unhap-
py wife was taken up lifeless. His phrenzy and
despair may be imagined. but cannot be described.


STATE LEGISLATURE.


NeW York, March 12.--In the House, several
petitions were presented from citizens of the west
ern countless for aid in investigating the mysterious
circumstance ofthe disappearance Of William Nor
gan. The petitions were referred to the commit.
lee on courts of justice.


Philadelphia, March 13.-The collection in the
Baptist Church in Second street. on Thursday even
ing last. for the benefit Of the Creeks was 16O dol
lars. The whole fund now exceeds Is 1000 dollars


81. .angusine, { East Florida, } Feb 81


FLORIDA SUGAR We have received specimen Of
nounced by Judges be superior the best Havana
gar Col Whe writes that he has received letters from
a dozen planters in North Carolina and Virginia, making
known their determination to to Florida and ask
ing for information. Col. Dumme told, will make
80 Hhds Sugar. notwithstanding the disadvantages under
which he labored, from about 35 acres of Cane.

notice, because it shows how extensive the trade
of the city must be which exhibits such an appear.
ance on one OF its numerous avenues-and it also
serves strongly to illustrate the Importance and
value of the contemplated Rail Road to the West.
the advantages of which, when compared with
those Of the ordinary turnpike road, are as twenty
to one in favor Of the former.-B Bait. american.


The Legislature of the State of VIRGINIA has
passed law confirming the Charter of the BaIti-
more and Ohio Rail Road Company. with only these
alterations: 1s. That the road shall not touch the
Ohio river lower down than the mouth of Little
kanawha river; that the damages for property ta-
ken or used for the construction Of the road, &C.
shal be determined as such affairs are now effected
by the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia; that
the penalty for inurng the road or property Of
Company, shall be the same as is inflicted for the
same offence against the public works of Virginia,
that is, the Penitentiary. The bill passed both
Houses Of the Legislature by an almost unanimous
vote.
